ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with this course compared to others you have taken was:
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
How would you rate the workload of this course in comparison to other F&ES courses you have taken?
Given the course objectives, the level of intellectual challenge of the material covered was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I learned a lot about different disciplines within food justice such as urban political ecology and critical race theory. The biggest insight I gained from the course is that food justice movements within local movements is connected to a larger food justice movement globally. Although the local movements may be different, the principles and goals are similar. I also learned how to work with a client and how to conduct efficient group work.

I learnt about social justice dimensions of todays globalized food system, considering justice in terms of sociopolitical and environmental dynamics (topics included: food sovereignty, agroecology, food regimes, Black agrarianism, and gender & agriculture etc). Also, through the capstone part of the course, we got to work with Farm School NYC (NY Food Justice Organization/NGO to be) and was able to connect theory and practice. Through that process we learnt how to present better, write proposals, arrive at a research question that would be useful to the organization etc.

narratives.question_text: How well did the knowledge, skills, and insights gained in this class align with your expectations?
comments: It exceeded my expectations. Professor Reynolds is a very insightful and provides space for every student to participate.
It aligned well, and I got what I expected out of this class.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of the course and how could it be improved?
comments: The weakness of the course is that there is a lot of material to learn and very little time. The course is really good despite that. There are a lot of strengths in the course. It is meant to provide real world experience in food justice work, which it does. It also provides a space to talk about food justice and is the only course at FES that does this.

Strengths: Interesting readings, good because it combined practice and theory - although we did cover a lot of topics, and sometimes discussion did feel quite on-the-surface since we just move onto something different the next week Weakness: If I was being very finicky I would say it could be structured a bit better but overall a really good course!

narratives.question_text: What advice would you give to a student considering taking this class?
comments: Be prepared to truly engage with the material. It's not a class you can necessarily coast in.
If you're interested in food/environmental justice and also working with non/not-for-profit organizations in the future, I would highly recommend this course.
